Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award Grant for Identifying changes in serotonin receptor function due to naturally occurring single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project at Fisk University is to identify novel signaling pathways that may be used by the serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT) receptor which are revealed by examining subtly modified receptor structures, such as those encoded by single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) found in human individuals. The objectives of the proposed research are to introduce into heterologous cells cDNAs encoding natural occurring polymorphic 5-HT2CRs whose sequence modifications are in regions previously identified as critical for coupling to G protein-mediated signaling pathways, and to characterize the functional consequences of these SNP-encoded sequence modifications. At least two undergraduate students per year will be involved in the research. Furthermore, master?s students in the lab will serve as role models for the undergraduates.

The project will study the functional consequences of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the serotonin (5-HT) 2C receptor. 5-HT is a neurotransmitter that modulates a variety of neurophysiological responses by binding to one of 14 different receptor subtypes, one of which is the 5-HT2C receptor (5-HT2CR). The 5-HT2CR is a seven-transmembrane (7TM) spanning, G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) that is involved in neuronal excitability, spatial learning, and appetite. Recent studies reveal that GPCRs may be a misnomer since many 7TM Receptors also activate cellular processes via non-G protein-coupled responses, primarily via the protein arrestin. The relative contribution of G Protein versus arrestin-mediated signaling is not well understood for the 5-HT2CR. SNPs identified in humans, which can lead to changes in protein sequence and, in some cases, altered activities, can provide insights into critical structure-function relationships of a protein. Though over 2,000 SNPs have been identified in the human 5-HT2CR, little characterization of structural and functional consequences of those SNPs has occurred, and no studies have explored whether or not such changes in receptor structure modify the preferential signaling via G protein-coupled versus arrestin-mediated pathways.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Serotonin (5-HT) is a neurotransmitter that modulates a variety of neurophysiological responses by binding to one of 14 different receptor subtypes, one of which is the 5-HT2C receptor. The goals of our research were to identify novel signaling pathways as well as alterations in known pathways that may be used by the 5-HT2C receptor which can be revealed by examining modified structures due to mutations that are found in humans.  During our studies, we discovered that the 5-HT2C receptor can activate a pathway it has never been shown to activate before, the janus kinase/signal transducer and activator of transcription (JAK/STAT) pathway. The human 5-HT2C receptor activates the JAK/STAT pathway by phosphorylating STAT3. This activation is constitutive as cells expressing the 5-HT2C receptor cause phosphorylation (activation by adding a phosphate group) of STAT3 in the absence of agonist stimulation. The JAK/STAT pathway is a highly conserved pathway used by cytokines and hormones such as prolactin, growth hormone and erythropoietin that lead to transcription of genes associated with numerous responses. These responses include cell differentiation, growth, proliferation, and the immune response.  Also, our goals were to clone natural occurring mutations in the human 5-HT2C receptor, express them into cells, and examine them for changes in signaling.

Given that there are not many good commercial antibodies for the recognition of 5-HT2C receptor, we first created a fluorescently tagged receptor (on the end of the protein) in order to identify the receptors once they were expressed in cells (figure 1).  We created the following mutations: Ala57Pro, Pro108Ser, Pro280Leu, Arg297Met, and Thr419Ala. Next we generated cell lines that expressed these different isoforms of the receptor. We have examined their ability to activate the JAK/STAT pathway. Some of these mutations have decreased activation of the JAK/STAT pathway.

We also evaluated the ability of violacein, a purple pigment produced by the organism Chromobacterium violaceum to have activity at the 5-HT2C receptor. Violacein is synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan just like serotonin. We discovered that violacein may be a novel antagonist (blocker) at the 5-HT2C receptor. This may lead to violacein being used in disorders in which there is too much serotonergic signaling or improper serotonergic control.

We also cloned the chicken 5-HT2C receptor and examined the effects of different diets (a low fat diet versus a high fat diet) on 5-HT2C receptor expression in the hypothalamus, a region in the brain that controls appetite. Our results show that low fat diets increase 5-HT2C receptor expression in the hypothalamus of chickens and decreased their fat content. This shows that the 5-HT2C receptor expression in the chicken can be regulated by diet and can be used to produce more lean chicken. Also, our data may lead to new strategies to change the ratios of fat and amino acids like tryptophan in the diet of chicken and other feed animals in order to increase 5-HT2C receptor expression in the brain.

These studies have provided research training and developmental activities for 2 high school students, 16 undergraduate students and 6 graduate students from 3 different universities: Fisk University, Tennessee State University, and Middle Tennessee State University. Our results have been presented at many Metro Nashville Public Schools, Tennessee State University, Meharry Medical College, the Tennessee Physiology Society Annual Meeting, the Society for Neuroscience, the Experimental Biology Annual Meeting, and an Emory University STEM Conference. They have also provided a venue for the PI to develop professionally as he has attended many conferences, been invited to give lectures, as well as attend workshops sponsored by the National Science Foundation and the Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network. The PI has given many short talks entitled “Life as a Neuroscientist” at Carter Lawrence Elementary Math and Science Magnet School, Eakin Elementary, Shayne Elementary, and to the Cane Ridge High School's Science Club, all public schools in the metro Nashville public school system. He has also presented to Lake Providence Missionary Baptist Church Summer Enrichment Program (K-8). 

This project and award has allowed us to bring equipment, technologies, and a new area of research to Tennessee State University that has dramatically increased both undergraduate and graduate interest
in neuroscience research.

Modified by: Hugh Fentress

    Hugh Fentress
    Fluorescent serotonin 2C receptor
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Serotonin (5-HT) is a neurotransmitter that modulates a variety of neurophysiological responses by binding to one of 14 different receptor subtypes, one of which is the 5-HT2C receptor. The goals of our research were to identify novel signaling pathways as well as alterations in known pathways that may be used by the 5-HT2C receptor which can be revealed by examining modified structures due to mutations that are found in humans. During our studies, we discovered that the 5-HT2C receptor can activate a pathway it has never been shown to activate before, the janus kinase/signal transducer and activator of transcription (JAK/STAT) pathway. The human 5-HT2C receptor activates the JAK/STAT pathway by phosphorylating STAT3. This activation is constitutive as cells expressing the 5-HT2C receptor cause phosphorylation (activation by adding a phosphate group) of STAT3 in the absence of agonist stimulation. The JAK/STAT pathway is a highly conserved pathway used by cytokines and hormones such as prolactin, growth hormone and erythropoietin that lead to transcription of genes associated with numerous responses. These responses include cell differentiation, growth, proliferation, and the immune response. Also, our goals were to clone natural occurring mutations in the human 5-HT2C receptor, express them into cells, and examine them for changes in signaling. Given that there are not many good commercial antibodies for the recognition of 5-HT2C receptor, we first created a fluorescently tagged receptor (on the end of the protein) in order to identify the receptors once they were expressed in cells (figure 1). We created the following mutations: Ala57Pro, Pro108Ser, Pro280Leu, Arg297Met, and Thr419Ala. Next we generated cell lines that expressed these different isoforms of the receptor. We have examined their ability to activate the JAK/STAT pathway. Some of these mutations have decreased activation of the JAK/STAT pathway. We also evaluated the ability of violacein, a purple pigment produced by the organism Chromobacterium violaceum to have activity at the 5-HT2C receptor. Violacein is synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan just like serotonin. We discovered that violacein may be a novel antagonist (blocker) at the 5-HT2C receptor. This may lead to violacein being used in disorders in which there is too much serotonergic signaling or improper serotonergic control. We also cloned the chicken 5-HT2C receptor and examined the effects of different diets (a low fat diet versus a high fat diet) on 5-HT2C receptor expression in the hypothalamus, a region in the brain that controls appetite. Our results show that low fat diets increase 5-HT2C receptor expression in the hypothalamus of chickens and decreased their fat content. This shows that the 5-HT2C receptor expression in the chicken can be regulated by diet and can be used to produce more lean chicken. Also, our data may lead to new strategies to change the ratios of fat and amino acids like tryptophan in the diet of chicken and other feed animals in order to increase 5-HT2C receptor expression in the brain. These studies have provided research training and developmental activities for 2 high school students, 16 undergraduate students and 6 graduate students from 3 different universities: Fisk University, Tennessee State University, and Middle Tennessee State University. Our results have been presented at many Metro Nashville Public Schools, Tennessee State University, Meharry Medical College, the Tennessee Physiology Society Annual Meeting, the Society for Neuroscience, the Experimental Biology Annual Meeting, and an Emory University STEM Conference. They have also provided a venue for the PI to develop professionally as he has attended many conferences, been invited to give lectures, as well as attend workshops sponsored by the National Science Foundation and the Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network. The PI has given many short talks entitled "Life as a Neuroscientist" at Carter Lawrence Elementary Math and Science Magnet School, Eakin Elementary, Shayne Elementary, and to the Cane Ridge High School's Science Club, all public schools in the metro Nashville public school system. He has also presented to Lake Providence Missionary Baptist Church Summer Enrichment Program (K-8). This project and award has allowed us to bring equipment, technologies, and a new area of research to Tennessee State University that has dramatically increased both undergraduate and graduate interest in neuroscience research.
